definition[0]: not more than a particular number, age etc
example[0]: Naomi was only 17 when she got married.
example[1]: There are only a few cars on the island.
definition[1]: used to say that something or someone is not very important, serious etc
example[4]: It’s an interesting job, but it’s only temporary.
example[5]: They’re only small cuts, nothing life-threatening.
definition[2]: nothing or no one except a particular person or thing
example[6]: Only the president can authorize a nuclear attack.
example[7]: We use only the best ingredients.
example[8]: The car park is for staff only.
definition[3]: used to say that something happens or is possible in one particular situation or place and no others, or for one particular reason
example[9]: I’ll tell you, but only if you don’t tell anyone else.
example[10]: I ate the food, but only because I was starving.
example[11]: The transfer takes place only when the data is complete.
explanation[0]: Only usually comes between the subject and the main verb
explanation[1]: Only usually comes between an auxiliary verb and a main verb
example[13]: I can only see two people
explanation[2]: When you want to emphasize what you are saying, you sometimes use only at the beginning of a sentence, and put the auxiliary verb before the subject
example[14]: Only later did  I understand what she meant
example[15]: Only by improving social and economic conditions can good health be achieved
definition[4]: no earlier than a particular time
example[17]: Only then did she tell him about the attack.
note[2]: only then did/would/could etc somebody do something
definition[5]: used to say that there is one person, thing, or group in a particular situation and no others
example[18]: I was the only woman there.
example[20]: I was the only one who disagreed.
example[21]: Cutting costs is the only solution.
example[22]: She’s the only person for this job.
definition[6]: used like ‘but’ to give the reason why something is not possible
example[23]: I’d offer to help, only I’m really busy just now.
